title: Protocol for inducing cellular ablation in the mouse atrioventricular conduction system
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Induction of AVCS cellular ablation by Tamoxifen
Timing: 1 min/adult mouse, 5 min/neonatal mouse
In this step, we describe the intraperitoneal (i.p.), per orem (p.o.), and subcutaneous (s.c.) administration of Tamoxifen on adult (P42) and neonatal (P0) mice. Unlike adult mice given Tamoxifen for 7 days, we decided to do a single-day administration of Tamoxifen on neonatal mice to minimize maternal cannibalization.
Intraperitoneal (i.p.) administration of Tamoxifen on adult mice (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2518-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Administration of Tamoxifen solution to adult and neonatal mice
(A) Intraperitoneal (i.p.) administration on adult mice.
(B) Per orem (p.o.) administration on neonatal mice.
(C) Subcutaneous (s.c.) administration on neonatal mice.
On day 0, place adult (P42) mouse on metal grid and grab loose skin at the back of the neck between your thumb and forefinger.
Hold tail with little and ring finger.
Perform injection of a single dose of 1 mg Tamoxifen.
Aim for the lower right abdomen with the needle directed towards the thorax in a 30°–40° angle to minimize risk of puncturing intestinal organs.
Perforate skin and slowly aspirate.
If there is no aspirated liquid (i.e., blood or green liquid), administer Tamoxifen solution.
Note: Insulin syringe is preferred (e.g., BD Insulin Syringe, NK, USA), as these diameters are less likely to perforate intestinal organs and hurt the mouse, compared to larger needles.
Repeat steps a.-b. for day 1–7 of Tamoxifen induction on adult mice.
Per orem (p.o.) administration of Tamoxifen on neonatal mice (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
On day 0, collect entire litter of neonatal (P0) mice and place in a separate cage.
Gently grab a neonatal mouse at the back of the neck and visualize the animal’s mouth.
Using a pipettor, get 8–10 μL of Tamoxifen equivalent to a single 0.8–1 mg dose.

Position the pipette tip in the animal’s mouth and slowly administer the Tamoxifen solution.
Note: Give the neonatal mouse time to swallow the solution and hold the animal upright to ensure ingestion of the Tamoxifen.
Put the neonatal mouse in an extra cage to allow recovery until other neonatal mice are given Tamoxifen.
Relocate all neonatal mice (i.e., entire litter) to their original cage after induction.
Subcutaneous (s.c.) administration of Tamoxifen on neonatal mice (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
On day 0, collect entire litter of neonatal (P0) mice and place in a separate cage.
Gently put your thumb and forefinger to the middle of the thoracic spine to immobilize the animal.
Perform injection of a single dose of 1 mg Tamoxifen.
Aim for the skin at the back of the neck with the needle directed towards the tail in a 20°–30° angle.
Perforate skin and slowly administer Tamoxifen solution.
Put the neonatal mouse in an extra cage to allow recovery until other neonatal mice are given Tamoxifen.
Relocate all mice to their original cage after induction.
ECG recording of adult and neonatal mice
Timing: 10 min/mouse
In this step, we show how to perform electrocardiography (ECG) on adult and neonatal mice to check for the effect of AVCS cellular ablation after Tamoxifen induction.
Anesthetize mice for ECG with 2% isoflurane in 2.0 L/min O2.
Adult anesthesia:
Place adult mouse in anesthesia chamber.
Once anesthetized, place the animal at the mouse pad and hook to rodent facemask.
Neonatal anesthesia:
Place neonatal mouse in the mouse pad.
Hook animal directly to rodent facemask.
Note: Assess depth of anesthesia by checking loss of righting reflex or response to pain stimulation (e.g., toe pinch).
Place subcutaneous ECG electrodes in the conventional lead II position (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2518-Fig4.jpg

Figure 4. Electrocardiography (ECG) conventional lead II placement in neonatal and adult mice
(A) Schematic of conventional lead II placement of ECG electrodes.
(B) Actual conventional lead II placement of ECG electrodes in neonatal mouse.
(C) Actual conventional lead II placement of ECG electrodes in adult mouse.
Place positive (red) electrode at the left forelimb.
Place negative (black) electrode at the right forelimb.
Place reference (green) electrode at the left hindlimb.
Note: Clean mouse limbs and ECG electrodes with alcohol pads before inserting them into the mouse.
Once ECG electrodes are in place, click start at the LabChart 8 program to record the animal’s ECG.
Record ECG for at least one to one-and-a-half minutes.
Remove ECG electrodes once recording is finished and return the animal to its cage.
Repeat on subsequent days as necessary.

Note: Minimize the influence of isoflurane on the heart rate by doing the following: (1) Minimize isoflurane induction time (neonatal mice induction time is longer compared to adult mice); (2) Calculate ECG measurements (i.e., PR interval, QRS interval, etc.) on the first 30 s of an ECG tracing.
Optional: Since mice PR interval shortens as they grow, perform ECG on normal mice of different ages (e.g., P7, P14, p21, p28) to determine normal PR interval values for each age group. Normal PR interval range was set as Mean ± 2 Standard Deviation in Wang et al.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] (Table 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl4]).
Pharmacological challenge post-Tamoxifen induction
Timing: 10 min/mouse
In this step, we describe how to perform pharmacological studies using Atropine and Isoproterenol injection to further check the effect of AVCS cellular ablation after Tamoxifen induction.
Freshly prepare pharmacological agents, i.e., Atropine and Isoproterenol.

After recording ECG for 1 min, perform IP injection of pharmacological agents at a dose of 2 μg/g or 50 ng/g of Atropine or Isoproterenol, respectively.
Continue recording the animal’s ECG for 5 min following drug administration.
Mice preparation for heart removal
Timing: 30 min
In the following steps, we show how to collect and process mice hearts for immunohistological staining and analysis.
Place mice in an empty cage and slowly fill with CO2 at 3L/min.
Wait until euthanasia is complete (i.e., no more breathing can be observed).
Perform cervical dislocation as secondary method of euthanasia.
Place euthanized mice in a clean dissection pad.
Cut the chest open and expose the chest cavity.
Cut the major blood vessels connecting the heart to the cardiac base.
Place harvested heart in cold 1× PBS.
Gently pump the harvested heart with forceps to remove excess blood.
Preparation and X-Gal staining of mouse heart for paraffin block and sliced sections
Timing: 2–3 days
Fix the harvested heart in 0.2% glutaraldehyde for one (1) hour at 4°C.
Wash with washing buffer for 10 min twice.
Incubate and shake the harvested heart in X-gal staining buffer at room temperature (20°C–22°C) overnight (12–16 h), covered with foil.
Post-fix the harvested heart in neutral formalin overnight (12–16 h) for paraffin embedding.
Critical: (Para-)Formaldehyde solution is a harmful material for humans. Handling (para-)formaldehyde solution should be done inside a chemical fume hood and wearing protective gear such as glasses, lab coat, and gloves.
Place the harvested heart in a mold in the appropriate orientation.
Embed harvested heart in paraffin.
Pause point: Paraffin blocks can be stored at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for years.
Section the mouse heart paraffin block in a posterior to anterior (PA) direction.
Collect sections where mitral valve and tricuspid valve are present.

Preparation of mouse heart for frozen block and sliced sections
Timing: 1–2 days
Fix the harvested heart in 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) for one (1) hour at 4°C.
Sequentially incubate the harvested heart in 10% and 20% sucrose/PBS at 4°C for 12–24 h.
Fill a cryomold with Tissue Freezing Medium (TFM).
Place the harvested heart in the TFM-filled cryomold.
Orient the harvested heart into the four-chamber orientation.
Snap-freeze the harvested heart with TFM using dry ice or liquid nitrogen.
Store mouse heart frozen block at –80°C prior to sectioning.
Section the mouse heart frozen block into 8-micron slices in a posterior to anterior (PA) direction, using a Leica CM3050S cryostat.
Collect sections where septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve is present.
Pause point: Frozen sections can be stored at –80°C for years.
Histological staining protocol
Timing: 24–48 h
For paraffin sections:
Wash paraffin sections with 100% Cedarwood Oil (CWO) for 5 min three times to deparaffinize sections.
Wash sections with 1:1 CWO and 100% ethanol for 2 min.
Rinse sections three times with 100% ethanol for 5 min.
Rinse sections three times with running water for 5 min.
For cryosections:
Air-dry tissue sections for 15–20 min at room temperature (20°C–22°C).
Wash thoroughly with PBS for 2 min twice.
Note: Be careful of washing/rinsing cryosections as they come off the slide easier.
Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining.
Incubate sections in Harris hematoxylin for 5 s.
Wash thoroughly in running water for 5 min.
Incubate sections in 100% alcohol for 10 s.
Incubate sections in eosin for 5 s.
Wash sections in alcohol for 5 s three times, with one final wash in 100% alcohol for 10 s.
Wash sections in xylene for 10 s, and another two washes in xylene for 5 s each.
Seal sections with cover slips and mounting medium.

Masson’s Trichrome (MTC) staining.
Immerse sections in Bouin’s Fluid (preheated to 56°C) for 60 min or overnight (12–16 h) at room temperature (20°C–22°C).
Note: All reagents are obtained from Trichrome One-Step Blue & Red Stain kit (#KTTRBPT, American MasterTech Scientific) unless otherwise noted.
Rinse sections with running water for 3 min or until sections are colorless.
Immerse sections in Modified Mayer’s Hematoxylin for 7 min.
Rinse sections with running water for 3 min.
Immerse sections in One-Step Trichrome Stain (Blue & Red) for 3–8 min.
Rinse sections with running water for 5 s.
Rinse sections three times with absolute alcohol for 1 min.
Rinse sections three times with Xylene for 1 min.
Seal sections with cover slips and mounting medium.
Nuclear-fast red (NFR) staining.
Incubate sections in Nuclear Fast Red solution for 5 min.
Rinse sections with running water for 5 min.
Wash sections three times with 100% ethanol for 2 min.
Rinse sections three times with Xylene for 1 min.
Seal sections with cover slips and mounting medium.
Acetylcholinesterase activity staining.
Incubate sections in Acetylthiocholine staining buffer at 37°C overnight (12–16 h).
Rinse section slides with distilled water.
Counterstain section slides with eosin (steps 39d–g).
Seal sections with cover slips and mounting medium.
Immunostaining protocol for cryosections
Timing: 2–3 days
Air-dry fixed tissue sections for 15–20 min at room temperature (20°C–22°C).
Wash sections three times with PBS for 5 min.
Add 0.3% Triton-X100 in PBS to the fixed sections and allow permeabilization for 20 min at room temperature (20°C–22°C).
Wash sections three times with PBS for 5 min.
Block fixed sections with Universal Blocking buffer for 10 min at room temperature (20°C–22°C).
Dilute primary antibodies in the appropriate amount and apply 30 μL to each section.
Incubate overnight (12–16 h) at 4°C.

Wash sections three times with PBS for 5 min.
Dilute secondary antibodies in the appropriate amount and apply 30 μL to each section.
Incubate for 1 h at room temperature (20°C–22°C).
Wash sections with PBS.
Mount tissue sections with Vectashield Mounting Medium with DAPI.
